Exaggerate: The claim states that the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council have conducted 99.99 percent of the total nuclear tests, which may be an exaggeration.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or sources to support the statement that the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council have conducted 99.99 percent of the total nuclear tests.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the possibility of alternative explanations for the number of nuclear tests conducted, such as tests conducted by countries other than the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there have been as many as 13 nuclear tests conducted by countries other than the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the number of nuclear tests conducted by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council is accurate without providing concrete evidence or sources to support this assumption.
